short_desc: 15,000 marbles create images which reference the ecological environment a visitor might experience when visiting Prince's Island Park.
desc1: Four pixilated images represent the flora and fauna of the area in a spontaneous and unique fashion. The marbles shimmer and shift in colour depending on the time of day, while the images become abstracted the closer the viewer stands to the sculptures themselves. Look closely. Can you see yourself?

title: The Colour of Snow
address: Nosehill Drive overpass at Crowchild Trail N.W .
short_desc: Conceptually and visually linked to the watercolour-like glass on the LRT station windows, the artwork in these railings is inspired by the artist's first visit to Calgary.
desc1: These 24 snowflake patterns emulate a snowstorm, drawing our attention to the unique forms that are built by nature, in an environment built by man. Pedestrians are able to enjoy the railings on a personal level, engaging with both the infrastructure and the shadows they cast as they walk by.

title: Flock
address: Rocky Ridge Recreation Facility: 11300 Rocky Ridge Rd. N.W.
short_desc: Sited between the wetland and the front of Rocky Ridge Recreation Facility, this flock of birds rises from the wetland into the sky.
desc1: Inspired by wetland birds when they take flight, this artwork is responsive to the changing seasons, weather, and light conditions. Poles arranged in a v-shape support a flock of wind vane birds that move in the wind and glint with the sunlight. The shape and colouration of the vanes are loosely inspired by geese. The angle formed by the lowest vane on each pole are designed to point to the position of the sun in the sky at noon on the Winter Solstice.

title: Fish Ladder
artist: Caitlind r.c. Brown and Wayne Garrett
address: Elbow Island Park - Fourth Street S.W. and Elbow Drive S.W.
short_desc: The gateway to Elbow Island Park, this staircase marks the transition from urban to natural as you enter the park.
desc1: As described by the artists, "the stairs reference fish skeletons, the ribs of a canoe, and ripples in water. As you move down the stairs onto Elbow Island Park, materials transition from steel to wood, indicating a change from urban to natural. Drooping stairs create a moiré pattern, rippling underfoot. You become the stone skipping across water. Over time, foliage will grow up through the stairs, integrating them into the park."

title: Views
address: Confederation Park and 10th Street N.W. pedestrian underpass
short_desc: Approaching from another angle or taking a closer look can enlighten, revealing strange ideas and new beauty.
desc1: These spray painted murals were part of the Street Art Program for Youth and can be found in the pedestrian underpass at Confederation park. The corrugated steel surface of the tunnel has a distortive effect on images - the 'scenes' from the park reveal themselves only at certain angles, otherwise they are rendered as abstract bursts of colour. Up close, rosehips can seem alien as asteroids (or giant meatballs, as one young passerby quipped).
desc2: These views of the park are intended to encourage us all to pay close attention to the world around us, and to take a few steps back every once in a while to gain some perspective.

title: Passages
address: Glenmore/Ogden Bridge Pier Interchange S.E.
short_desc: Passages draws inspiration from Ogden's past, present and future modes of transportation.
desc1: The artwork references to the natural environment and architecture as well as the evolution of pedestrian traffic to contemporary commuting. These mosaics use familiar imagery of local history, abstracted forms and saturated colours expressing the excitement and energy of a city in motion.

title: Bronze Spaceflower
address: Telus Convention Centre
short_desc: This sculpture was inspired by the unknown territories of outer space and the deep sea.
desc1: Created by renowned Edmonton artist Roy Leadbeater, a former sailor and power engineer, this bronze abstraction was originally purchased by Leo Sheftel who was the first Chairman of the Calgary Convention Centre. It was later gifted to the City of Calgary by the Sheftel family.

title: One Eighty
address: Chinook LRT, 61st Avenue and 1A Street S.W.
short_desc: This functional sculpture serves as a bike rack near the busy Chinook LRT station and speaks to movement and making different choices for a better future.
desc1: By changing your lifestyle, you can change your community and your world. By choosing to cycle rather than drive, you can improve your health and your environment. This artwork promotes cycling and the use of Calgary's bike paths, while representing the history of transportation.
desc2: The rim of the wheel sculpture is made entirely of City of Calgary Transit 1942 railroad track.  The spokes are made from oil well sucker rod. The bike racks are made from oil well pipe.

title: DayNight Art - Windshields
address: 3375 Spruce Dr. S.W.
short_desc: You can take shelter from the wind thanks to three structural wind blocking pieces. These wind shields celebrate nature and represent Ethiopian and Ukrainian cultural symbolism in the form of coffee bean and egg shapes.
desc1: A collaboration between Calgary artists Oksana Kryzhanivska and Sisay Shimeles, the designs for the artwork were conceived during multi-cultural art workshops with Spruce Cliff community members that focused on cross-cultural and traditional ways of art making. With the goal of uniting multicultural artists and building stronger community ties that would highlight Spruce Cliff's identity, participants produced paintings that were incorporated into the final art pieces.
desc2: Iconic references from the artists' cultural background, the coffee bean and egg shape, frame transparent collages of the artists' work and community members' paintings. Viewers are encouraged to stand at different places in the area and witness the half shapes becoming full.

title: Robert Chambers Edwards, Publisher (1864-1922)
address: Municipal Building Atrium
short_desc: Still wearing his suit, his tie loosened, with a slight forward slouch to his seated posture, this figure appears weary and thoughtful.
desc1: Robert Edwards, the maverick publisher and editor of Calgary's Eye Opener newspaper from 1902-1922, was intense, witty, inventive and often combative. He was a tireless defender of his community and could be a fierce opponent. In this small character study, the artist imagines him in an unguarded moment at the end of a working day.
desc2: Created by prominent Métis artist David Garneau, a well-known contemporary artist, curator, writer, and professor, this ceramic sculpture is part of a series of five figures representing Alberta's past. In 1984 when he was commissioned to create sculptures of historic Calgarians to commemorate Calgary's 100th birthday, he was a 22 year-old student. At the time he was greatly influenced by the small-scale character studies in ceramic by Saskatchewan artist Joe Fafard.

title: José María Morelos y Pavon
address: Tomkins Park (17th Avenue and Eighth Street S.W.)
short_desc: This bronze bust is a small piece of Mexican history that was generously given to the City of Calgary.
desc1: The man shown in the bust, José María Morelos y Pavon (1765-1815), was a key figure in the Mexican War of Independence. Both a Roman Catholic priest and a revolutionary, he led multiple campaigns for Mexican independence from the Spanish Empire.
desc2: Although he was executed prior the end of Spanish rule in 1821, he is widely respected as a Mexican hero whose efforts were essential to the country's autonomy.
desc3: The bust of Morelos was a gift to the City of Calgary from Mexico. It marks 200 years of Mexican independence. It was officially unveiled in Calgary's Tomkins Park on September 16, 2011, Mexico's annual day of independence.

title: Past, Present and Future
address: James Short Park, 115 Fourth Ave. S.W.
short_desc: Gernot Kiefer's limestone sculpture is an artistic representation of the progression of people though time.
desc1: Roughly resembling a human head, this sculpture has marks on its surface, intended to represent the time periods referenced in the work's title: the past, present and future. Near the base of the sculpture, the rough surface suggests the challenges of the distant past.
desc2: Marks near the middle of the sculpture are placed closer together, mixed with sections of smooth stone, suggesting that the present provides a way of life that is both complex and perhaps less challenging than the past.
desc3: The upper portion of the sculpture is very smooth, suggesting the many possibilities of the future: what will humans do next?

title: Versus
address: New Brighton Athletic Park, 5801 130th Ave. S.E.
short_desc: An abbreviation for the term 'versus', this artwork characterizes the essence of competition that is inherent in various ways we relate to one another, especially when it comes to sports.
desc1: The intention is not to generate a sense of division or combativeness, but rather to distil the nature of competition in an engaging and iconic manner. The large steel sculpture speaks to the idea of opposing a competitor or of challenging oneself within a team setting. It is also applicable to larger conversations pertaining to global, social and economic issues.

title: Luminous Crossings
address: Downtown West - Kerby LRT Station (10th Street S.W.)
short_desc: This interactive public art installation consists of 20 components: two large-scale vertical sculptures, plus three hanging works, on four stations located at either end of the Seventh Avenue LRT line.
desc1: Referencing the idea of the living room or waiting area, there are four chandelier-like hanging sculptures in each canopy of the east and west gateway stations that give the waiting areas of the platforms a different quality. Additionally, their changing light show is a pleasant surrounding while waiting for the train.

title: Strung II
address: Crowchild Trail N.W. (Sarcee Trail N.W. Overpass)
short_desc: Strung II is comprised of two installations; one in the piers of the underpass along Crowchild Trail N.W. and the other in the railings of the overpass along Sarcee Trail N.W.
desc1: When considering the site, the artist was drawn to barbed wire imagery feeling it would be appropriate given this location had been ranch land in the recent past. He felt the use of this imagery would help to connect the site to that history.
desc2: From this he developed two types of experiences. The first is the large sculptural forms of barbed wire perched within the centre piers of the bridge. These are highly visible from a distance, and by C-Train and vehicular commuters who pass by on their daily commute.
desc3: The second is the laser cut panels on the Sarcee Trail overpass, which allow for a more personal pedestrian experience. Eight panels are inset within the railing, their connection implying a continuous string of barbed wire running from one end to the other. On a sunny day they cast shadows on the bridge deck and provide an alternate viewpoint for those engaging with the site.

title: Collected Stories: A Tribute to Georgina Thomson Library
address: Georgina Thomson Offices Exterior (772 Northmount Dr. N.W.)
short_desc: The public artwork for the latest incarnation of this historic building aims to honour the legacy of this former library and the late `answer lady' Georgina Thomson who worked here for many years.
desc1: Kari Woo developed her public art project to purposefully bridge the former use of the site with its new purpose as a neighbourhood services office.
desc2: Working alongside the local community and the family and friends of the late Georgina Thomson, she encouraged the exploration of the piece and its use in the new context to develop two installations that celebrate the site's past and present.
desc3: Outside the facility, Thomson's position as a librarian at this former library building is captured through a mini-library which invites visitors to take or leave a book. Beside this is a bench, engraved with the favourite quotes of community members, encouraging visitors to stop, gather and explore.

title: Boer War Memorial
address: Central Memorial Park (12th Avenue at Third Street S.W.)
short_desc: This huge, magnificent monument was meant to arouse lofty sentiments and patriotism.
desc1: A longstanding tradition, the equestrian statue was an especially fitting format to honour the 500 volunteers who travelled to South Africa from Alberta with their own horses. As horsemanship in the Boer war played a key role, the Montreal sculptor had a Western horse shipped to his studio.
desc2: The unknown mounted soldier is dressed in the uniform of Lord Strathcona's Horse regiment.

title: Self-Made Woman
artist: Paul Slipper with Cameron Small and Amiel Logan
address: SAIT Polytechnic (1301 16th Ave. N.W.)
short_desc: In this work, artist Paul Slipper, along with Cameron Small and Amiel Logan, offer a literal and lighthearted interpretation of a self-made woman: here, we see the figure carving herself out of granite.
desc1: "Self-Made Woman" was carved during WorldSkills Calgary 2009, a competition that brought attention to the value of skilled work in the trades, as well as in technology and the service industry.
desc2: The sculpture, which was carved in Calgary's Olympic Plaza before being moved to the SAIT campus, has both rough and smooth surfaces. These surfaces show how the work was made, with general forms being carved out and then gradually refined to produce a smooth and finished surface.
desc3: Slipper trained at the Emily Carr School of Art (now the Emily Carr University of Art and Design) and currently lives in Vancouver.

title: Pick, Pluck, Perch
address: 17th Avenue S.E. and 34th Street S.E.
short_desc: Selecting an unused corner on International Ave, artists Eric and Mia created a small social space focused on a gilded pear tree and refurbished planter where residents can harvest fruit and herbs.
desc1: This temporary public artwork is centred around a gilded pear tree that is under planted with companion plants and edible herbs and berries. As the tree grows, the gold will stretch, crack, and fall away. Over time the art will breakdown and the community will be left with a mature pear tree, berries, oregano, and thyme that residents are encouraged to harvest.
desc2: As the plants mature new habitats will be created for insects, birds and others. Complementing the vegetation are granite boulders as seating and a path made of reclaimed bricks that leads residents between the tree and the repurposed planter box.

title: Under the Helmet
address: Windsor Park Fire Station (5536 Fourth St. S.W.)
short_desc: Under the Helmet is a large aluminum sculpture of a firefighter's helmet, constructed from the characteristics of retired City of Calgary Fire hoses.
desc1: While visually simple in form, the artwork speaks to the complex relationships and dependencies that exist among firefighters and their equipment; fusing the personal protection the helmet offers and the uniform it represents into a monument to the profession.
desc2: During his research into the firefighting community, the artist was taken with the significance this piece of equipment holds to members of the Calgary Fire Department. The helmet distinguishes the individuality of the firefighter while symbolizing membership on a team, and represents the challenges and the rewards firefighters experience while under the helmet.

title: Family of Horses
address: Municipal Building plaza level, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E.
short_desc: Three unsaddled horses stand quietly on concrete steps of the City plaza, reminding us of the beauty of nature and wide open spaces of the prairie.
desc1: In this way, they offer temporary respite from the frenzy of our urban lives. They also speak to family. The mare turns to her foal while the stallion, standing behind them on higher ground, keeps a watchful eye.

title: Pete Pig
address: Plus 15, Third Street between Fourth & Fifth Avenue S.W.
short_desc: "Pete Pig" is a friendly fellow who lives in one of Calgary's many Plus-15 walkways. He sits cross-legged in his case, just waiting for a fellow citizen to stop by for a chat.
desc1: Gwen Hughes is the artist who created Pete from clay and acrylic paint. Born in Saskatchewan, Hughes now splits her time between Cochrane and California. She is known for her lighthearted portrayal of various animals, including pigs, cows, horses, and hippos. It was gifted to the City of Calgary from the Calgary Allied Arts Foundation in 1994.

title: Bearing
address: Fire Apparatus and Repair Facility (1755 18th Ave. N.E.)
short_desc: Inspired by the unseen work behind the doors of the Fire Apparatus and Repair Facility this multi piece installation is an abstracted representation of fastening and moving systems.
desc1: The personnel in this facility play a vital and supporting role to the Calgary Fire Department.  As behind the scenes work often goes uncelebrated, the artist's vision was to bring outside a larger than life representation of what occurs within the inside of this facility.
desc2: The arch is inspired by locking and flat wave washers, modified to create an iconic arch.  Further down site is a sphere reminiscent of ball bearings which are an integral part of any moving system. Settled into the ground, these works become both a singular and united element dependent upon the viewers position.

title: The Nest
address: Brookfield Residential YMCA at Seton, 45 Market St. S.E.
short_desc: This large nest communicates ideas of nurture, growth, discovery, and inclusivity at the Seton Recreation Facility.
desc1: Located in the central hub of the facility, a nest made of clear acrylic 'twigs' interlaced together suspends from the ceiling. Each hallway features a different flock of life-sized birds flying towards the nest. There are a total of thirty birds comprised of three different species. Community members selected the Swainson's Hawk, Great Blue Heron, and Great Horned Owl, birds familiar and loved by the Seton community.

title: Recollections (heating shelter glass)
address: McKnight/Westwinds LRT Station (6200 36th St. N.E.)
short_desc: This public artwork is one of four installations at this LRT station.
desc1: Located in the glass heating shelters on the LRT platform, these spheres of colour appear to be dots from a distance, dancing around the glass. But as viewers draw closer it is clear these dots contain photographs of people living everyday life.
desc2: A vital component of this public art project was the inclusion of community residents in the creation of the piece. One of four installations located at the McKnight/Westwinds LRT station, Recollections invites the viewer to learn more about the community members living in the area.
desc3: A call went out to Calgarians living in the N.E. to contribute images of their lives. From a historical photograph of Mrs. Brown with her brand new stove to an image of a resident's parents married in India in 1945, these photographs provide viewers a glimpse into significant personal, historical and community events; all of the elements that make this community a unique and special place.

title: Macleod Trail
address: Macleod Trail and 162nd Avenue S.E.
short_desc: Inspired by motion, the sky, the site, and nearby waterways, laser-cut metal panels span Macleod Trail along the bridge while two towers mark the pedestrian path.
desc1: The artist was inspired by the viewer's perception of motion they experience at different speeds, whether on foot, a bicycle, or in a car, as they move through the site. Patterns of undulating lines are featured throughout and are reminiscent of the geometry of the roadways as well as the rippling currents in nearby Fish Creek and the Bow River. At night the work is illuminated with subtly shifting vibrant colours.

title: Natural Engineer
address: Park East of the Municipal Building, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E.
short_desc: This life-size 'natural engineer' goes about his work without noticing the many people who pass by on their way to the Municipal Building Parkade.
desc1: Made by Cochrane-based sculptor Don Begg, this naturalistic bronze beaver is situated only a few blocks away from the Bow and Elbow Rivers.
desc2: Although these rivers flow through the heart of an urban centre, they are also the home of many creatures, including beavers.

title: Wolfe and the Sparrows
address: Southwest corner of 12th Street S.E. Bridge
short_desc: "Wolfe and the Sparrows" is a cast bronze sculpture inspired by an existing statue of General James Wolfe, sculpted by John Massey Rhind in 1898.
desc1: General Wolfe was an army general who led the British army to victory over the French during the Battle of the Plains of Abraham in 1759. "Wolfe and the Sparrows" may first appear to be a traditional monument, cast in bronze and raised on a pedestal. But as you move closer, it is revealed to be different: a flock of sparrows explodes from the figure, distorting Wolfe's head and shoulders.
desc2: By transforming the look of traditional monuments, it offers new ways to reflect on what these monuments say about our history.

title: Rhythms II
address: Village Square Leisure Centre (2623 56th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Two artful benches, full of whimsy, celebrate Village Square Leisure Centre and the services it provides to our community.
desc1: These functional sculptures use shapes and kinetic forms to provide a sense of movement, energy and vitality to connect the work to the theme of recreational activity. Bold colours represent the cultural vitality of the Centre, while images and motifs reflective of cultural groups are incorporated within, referencing the diversity of the community users of this facility.
desc2: Blue waves, Buddhist wheels, figures in motion and interactive activities invite you to sit, pause and maybe even play.

title: Comet
address: Pumphouse Theatre, 2140 Pumphouse Ave. S.W.
short_desc: This kinetic sculpture captures the essence and celestial quality of a comet streaking across our sky.
desc1: Originally made in 1983, years of Calgary's harsh climate had not been kind to the sculpture and it was restored by the artist in 2020. The nucleus of the comet is a swirling ball of steel, 15 feet high above the ground and will gently spin in the wind. The tail of the comet is a broad piece of steel that elegantly arcs and ends in a rudder to steer its path while it hurdles through space.
desc2: Following the repairs, the sculpture was painted an elusive deep space colour with metallic shimmer inspired by a piece of covellite rock the artist carries in her pocket.
